channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: How the coronavirus spread through one immigration facility
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Otay Mesa Detention Center would see the first big outbreak at U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement's 221 detention centers.
item.content:encoded: Otay Mesa Detention Center would see the first big outbreak at U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement's 221 detention centers.

media:content.media:description: Gregory Arnold, a former guard at the Otay Mesa Detention Center, poses for a picture Tuesday, May 12, 2020, in San Diego. The early absence of facial coverings, lack of cleaning supplies and mixing symptomatic detainees with others preceded the first big outbreak at U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement's 221 detention centers. While the point of origin is unclear, accounts of how the virus spread at the Otay Mesa Detention Center expose shortcomings and inherent difficulties of managing the world's largest immigration detention system during a pandemic. (AP Photo/Gregory Bull)

item.title: A fake congregation and tax schemes — California rabbi's years of fraud revealed
item.dc:creator: Greg Moran
item.description: Court records provide a detailed look at a sweeping years-long fraud scheme orchestrated by former Poway Chabad Rabbi Yisroel Goldstein.
item.content:encoded: Court records provide a detailed look at a sweeping years-long fraud scheme orchestrated by former Poway Chabad Rabbi Yisroel Goldstein.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this June 26, 2019, file photo, Rabbi Yisroel Goldstein, senior rabbi of Chabad of Poway synagogue in San Diego, Calif., addresses the United Nations General Assembly's meeting on combating antisemitism and other forms of racism and hate in the digital age at U.N. headquarters. The rabbi who had part of his hand shot off in a deadly attack at his Southern California synagogue pleaded guilty Tuesday, July 14, 2020, to federal charges of tax and wire fraud, according to a newspaper report. Rabbi Goldstein, 58, acknowledged his role in a scheme in which donors made large contributions to Chabad of Poway but then secretly got most of the money back, the San Diego Union-Tribune reported. (AP Photo/Bebeto Matthews, File)

item.dc:creator: Tony Barboza, Ben Poston
item.description: Pacific Islanders are seeing higher rates of infection from the coronavirus than any other racial or ethnic group in Los Angeles County.
item.content:encoded: Pacific Islanders are seeing higher rates of infection from the coronavirus than any other racial or ethnic group in Los Angeles County.

media:content.media:description: LONG BEACH, CA - JULY 08: Ili family from left: Taylor, 22, Aoga, 46, Lina, 46, Pele, 26, at their Long Beach condo, who had a harrowing experience in which half the family fell ill, where three of them had to be hospitalized with coronavirus. Photo taken on Wednesday, July 8, 2020 in Long Beach, CA. Pele Ili, 26, shot video chronicling the experience as his mother, father and brother contracted the coronavirus within a few days of one another and went to the hospital, leaving him as the eldest son to be their caretaker. The family is Samoan and Pacific Islanders have been hit especially hard by the virus. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Op-Ed: Serra's fall may further 'whiten' America's already too-white history
item.dc:creator: Steven W. Hackel
item.description: The desire to erase Serra may play into the hands of racists and white nationalists who seek to define America only in their image.
item.content:encoded: The desire to erase Serra may play into the hands of racists and white nationalists who seek to define America only in their image.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - JUNE 24: The bronze statue of Father Junipero Serra who founded nine Spanish missions in California including Mission San Buenaventura stands in front of Ventura City Hall. A joint statement was issued from local political, indigenous and Catholic leaders pledging to remove the monument, originally commissioned in the 1930s but replaced in 1989. "The time has come for the statue to be taken down and moved to a more appropriate nonpublic location," read the statement, issued by Ventura Mayor Matt LaVere. After a protest last weekend Ventura city spokeswoman Heather Sumagaysay said the city is making plans to host community discussions regarding the Serra statue and there is no timeline for its removal, she said. "It is our priority to be receptive to public concerns and provide an environment where all voices are heard and respected. A historic decision such as this will involve the voices of the Chumash tribe, the City Council and the residents of Ventura," Sumagaysay said in an emailed statement. "The city remains committed to collaborating with the community to determine next steps. We will inform the public of opportunities to participate and offer input at a future meeting." The move comes after a Father Serra statue was toppled last weekend on Olvera St. in downtown Los Angeles and people were considering changing the name of Ft Bragg, but voted the change down. Ventura City Hall on Wednesday, June 24, 2020 in Ventura, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Ask a Reporter
item.description: Join us weekly for a live video event in which L.A. Times journalists answer your questions about their coverage and behind-the-scenes action.
item.content:encoded: Being an L.A. Times journalist means going to interesting places, talking to fascinating people and seeing things that most people only ever read about. Many of those experiences are captured in the articles, videos and images we publish online and in print, but there's always more to the story. Our new live event series, "Ask a Reporter," is your chance to find out about the experiences journalists have that don't make it into their work. Each week, an L.A. Times reporter, photographer, columnist or videographer will answer your questions on our live video show. Visit our Twitter profile or our Facebook page to share your questions ahead of time and to sign up to receive an alert when the video begins. Here are the upcoming guests and topics for "Ask a Reporter."On July 21, photographer Jay Clendenin will talk about what it's like to photograph celebrities from afar because of the coronavirus with moderator and audience engagement editor Adriana Lacy.On July 28, reporter Ben Oreskes and columnist Erika Smith will discuss the homelessness crisis in Los Angeles. On August 4, reporter Sarah Wire will answer questions about the end of the U.S. congressional session and the upcoming election with moderator and audience engagement editor Adrienne Shih. Here are links to our "Ask a Reporter" events.

media:content.media:description: Follow the @latimes on Twitter and Facebook and join us weekly to chat live with a reporter about their job.

item.title: Parents, what are your questions about the coming school year?
item.dc:creator: Los Angeles Times Staff
item.description: Many schools in Southern California return to distance learning in the fall. Ask the L.A. Times your questions, and we'll do our best to get answers.
item.content:encoded: Many schools in Southern California return to distance learning in the fall. Ask the L.A. Times your questions, and we'll do our best to get answers.

media:content.media:description: MAR VISTA, CA - JULY 13, 2020 - - A pedestrian walks past Grand View Boulevard Elementary School with a marquee that still reads, "No School," in Mar Vista on July 13, 2020. Los Angeles campuses will not reopen for classes on Aug. 18, and the nation's second-largest school system will continue with online learning until further notice, because of the worsening coronavirus surge, Supt. Austin Beutner announced Monday. "Let me be crystal clear," Beutner said in an interview with The Times. "We all know the best place for students to learn is in a school setting." But, he said, "We're going in the wrong direction. And as much as we want to be back at schools and have students back at schools - can't do it until it's safe and appropriate." (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Junípero Serra statues to come down in Ventura, city leaders decide
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: When the statues will be removed has yet to be determined, but a resolution intends to relocate both to the mission.
item.content:encoded: When the statues will be removed has yet to be determined, but a resolution intends to relocate both to the mission.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - JUNE 24: Erica Cohee from Thousand Oaks photographs the bronze statue of Father Junipero Serra who founded nine Spanish missions in California including Mission San Buenaventura as it stands in front of Ventura City Hall. A joint statement was issued from local political, indigenous and Catholic leaders pledging to remove the monument, originally commissioned in the 1930s but replaced in 1989. "The time has come for the statue to be taken down and moved to a more appropriate nonpublic location," read the statement, issued by Ventura Mayor Matt LaVere. After a protest last weekend Ventura city spokeswoman Heather Sumagaysay said the city is making plans to host community discussions regarding the Serra statue and there is no timeline for its removal, she said. "It is our priority to be receptive to public concerns and provide an environment where all voices are heard and respected. A historic decision such as this will involve the voices of the Chumash tribe, the City Council and the residents of Ventura," Sumagaysay said in an emailed statement. "The city remains committed to collaborating with the community to determine next steps. We will inform the public of opportunities to participate and offer input at a future meeting." The move comes after a Father Serra statue was toppled last weekend on Olvera St. in downtown Los Angeles and people were considering changing the name of Ft Bragg, but voted the change down. Ventura City Hall on Wednesday, June 24, 2020 in Ventura, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

Los Angeles campuses will not reopen for classes on Aug. 18, and the nation's second-largest school system will continue with online learning until further notice, because of the worsening coronavirus surge, Supt. Austin Beutner announced Monday. "Let me be crystal clear," Beutner said in an interview with The Times. "We all know the best place for students to learn is in a school setting." But, he said, "We're going in the wrong direction. And as much as we want to be back at schools and have students back at schools - can't do it until it's safe and appropriate." (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 32 stranded chimpanzees need permanent new homes
item.dc:creator: Louis Sahagun
item.description: More than 500 exotic animals have been relocated since the troubled Wildlife Waystation surrendered its permits and shut down for good a year ago.
item.content:encoded: More than 500 exotic animals have been relocated since the troubled Wildlife Waystation surrendered its permits and shut down for good a year ago.

media:content.media:description: SYLMAR, CA - JULY 14, 2020 - - One of the 32 chimpanzees that still resides at the shuttered Wildlife Waystation on World Chimpanzee Day in the Angeles National Forest in Sylmar on July 14, 2020. The fate of the chimpanzees is uncertain because reputable sanctuaries willing to take them lack the funding needed to give the animals permanent new homes, officials say. The challenge now is finding the roughly $7 million it will take to build accommodations for the chimps at four reputable sanctuaries across the nation. A fundraiser was announced to help the sanctuaries take on these chimpanzees and to assist with the current care expenses of the primates while they wait at the Wildlife Waystation. More than 500 exotic animals including lions, tigers, alligators, wolves, owls and Vietnamese pot-bellied pigs have been relocated since the troubled 44-year-old center surrendered its California Department of Fish and Wildlife permits and shut down a year ago. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

But responding to public pressure in recent days, Newson has implied that a gradual reopening of beaches, parks and the economy following the coronavirus lockdown could begin as early as next week. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: The latest rallying cry of coronavirus deniers, brought to you by Orange County
item.dc:creator: Erika D. Smith
item.description: The last thing California needs is a government-sanctioned rallying cry about the safety of reopening schools in the pandemic. Thanks, Orange County.
item.content:encoded: The last thing California needs is a government-sanctioned rallying cry about the safety of reopening schools in the pandemic. Thanks, Orange County.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, Ca-July 13, 2020: A gate in front of Los Angeles High School on Rimpau Bvd. in Los Angeles is locked on July 13, 2020. Supt. Austin Beutner announced today that all schools in LAUSD, including Los Angeles High School will not re-open for classes on August 18, 2020, because of the coronavirus outbreak. The nation's second largest school system will continue with online learning until further notice. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Boy, 16, was given estrogen for behavioral disorder while in L.A. juvenile hall, suit alleges
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: A 16-year-old boy held in a Los Angeles juvenile hall was prescribed estrogen to treat a behavioral disorder, a practice several doctors say flies in the face of accepted medical doctrine, according to a lawsuit filed in late June. The boy developed enlarged breasts as a result and will need surgery, according to his attorney.
item.content:encoded: A 16-year-old boy held in a Los Angeles juvenile hall was prescribed estrogen to treat a behavioral disorder, a practice several doctors say flies in the face of accepted medical doctrine, according to a lawsuit filed in late June. Rivera rented the pontoon boat and had been swimming with her son who was the last one to see her before she went missing. The boy got back into the boat after a swim but his mother did not follow. Lake Piru on Monday, July 13, 2020 in Piru, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Aug. 13, 2019, file photo, pedestrians walk through the gates of Harvard Yard at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass. Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology filed a federal lawsuit Wednesday, July 8, 2020, challenging the Trump administration's decision to bar international students from staying in the U.S. if they take classes entirely online this fall. Some institutions, including Harvard, have announced that all instruction will be offered remotely in the fall during the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. (AP Photo/Charles Krupa, File)

item.content:encoded: After LAPD officers were charged with falsifying records, California's attorney general has stopped law enforcement statewide from using LAPD gang member records.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - MAY 2, 2019. Brian Allen is on the CalGang database though he is not a gang member. In 2017, he was driving with a friend when police pulled him over for expired tags. A year later, Allen received a letter informing him he'd been identified as a gang associate for being seen by police with this friend. He is still fighting to get off the database. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Community fridges show up in L.A. neighborhoods to feed those in need
item.dc:creator: Julissa James
item.description: Across L.A., community refrigerators with free food are popping up as part of a mutual aid network that aims to feed the hungry and eliminate food waste.
item.content:encoded: Across L.A., community refrigerators with free food are popping up as part of a mutual aid network that aims to feed the hungry and eliminate food waste.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 12, 2020 - - Jonah Mock, 41, center, owner of Little Amsterdam Coffee shop, shows the food that has been donated to the community refrigerator, that rests in front of his Midtown establishment, as his son Nolan, 14, looks on in Los Angeles on July 12, 2020. The coffee shop provides the electricity for the refrigerator and is located at 1412 S Redondo Blvd. It is filled with milk, fruit, cheese, tortillas, vegetables and readymade meals all donated by community members. Community fridges are popping up all over Los Angeles as part of a mutual aid project to feed people in need during the coronavirus pandemic. The fridges are painted with murals and bright colors, and are stocked with food inside donated by people from the community, local food banks and restaurants. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Despite criticism, LAPD Chief Michel Moore maintains support in political circles
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector, Dakota Smith, Richard Winton
item.description: Los Angeles officials have repeatedly ignored a central demand of the activists and protesters who inspired their broader turn away from the status quo in policing: the termination of Los Angeles Police Chief Michel Moore.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles officials have repeatedly ignored a central demand of the activists and protesters who inspired their broader turn away from the status quo in policing: the termination of Los Angeles Police Chief Michel Moore.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - SEPTEMBER 28, 2018 - LAPD Chief Michel Moore talks to recruits during uniform inspection of this graduating class at the Los Angeles Police Department graduation exercises for Recruit Officer Class of April 16, 2018 happening at the LAPD Elysian Park Academy on September 28, 2018. Officer John Beaty talks about being an African American recruit and about why he joined the LAPD. In this class, three of the 34 graduates are African American (10 Caucasian, 21 Hispanic, no Asians). Much has been made of the LAPD's ethnic demographics roughly mirroring those of the city. But the impact of policing still falls disproportionately on black residents. The percentage of officers who are black - roughly 9% - will soon plummet. A huge number of black officers will soon retire and recent academy classes consistently have only a few black members. New Police Chief Michel Moore says black recruiting is one of his main priorities. But in the post-Ferguson era, theres a struggle to fight the forces discouraging young black people from becoming police officers. LAPD officers in the field today say they are facing unprecedented hostility from other black people, both in the field and at home, who view them as sellouts. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Latino activists push for solidarity with Black community as they confront racism

item.description: Many Latino activists have sought to rally support for Black Lives Matter by emphasizing systemic inequities faced by both Latino and Black communities and recognizing anti-Black attitudes within Latino culture.
